<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 828, 94]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that \(7^{2n} - 1\) is divisible by 12 for every positive integer \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 868, 109]]<|/det|>
By simplifying \(\left(x^{n} - \sqrt{x^{2n} + 1}\right)\left(x^{n} + \sqrt{x^{2n} + 1}\right)\), show that \(\frac{1}{x^{n} - \sqrt{x^{2n} + 1}} = -x^{n} - \sqrt{x^{2n} + 1}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 191, 465, 217]]<|/det|>
Let \(u_{n} = x^{n + 1} + \sqrt{x^{2n + 2} + 1} + \frac{1}{x^{n} - \sqrt{x^{2n} + 1}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 234, 144, 252]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 655, 256]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to find \(\sum_{n = 1}^{N} u_{n}\) in terms of \(N\) and \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 234, 917, 253]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 186, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 536, 601, 560]]<|/det|>
Deduce the set of values of \(x\) for which the infinite series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 574, 567, 593]]<|/det|>
\[u_{1} + u_{2} + u_{3} + \ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 616, 625]]<|/det|>
is convergent and give the sum to infinity when this exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 604, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 393, 89]]<|/det|>
The matrices \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 101, 641, 149]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \text{and} \mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{2} & -\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{3} \\ \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{3} & \frac{1}{2} \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 144, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 816, 183]]<|/det|>
Give full details of the geometrical transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{A}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 146, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 814, 244]]<|/det|>
Give full details of the geometrical transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{B}\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 707, 432]]<|/det|>
The triangle \(DEF\) in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{AB}\) onto triangle \(PQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 611, 463]]<|/det|>
Show that the triangles \(DEF\) and \(PQR\) have the same area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 675, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the matrix which transforms triangle \(PQR\) onto triangle \(DEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 144, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 623, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = \ln (1 + \pi - \theta)\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 781, 123]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the polar coordinates of the point of \(C\) furthest from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 186, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 408, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(u = 1 + \pi - \theta\), or otherwise, show that the area of the region enclosed by \(C\) and the initial line is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 456, 645, 480]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{2} (1 + \pi)\ln (1 + \pi)(\ln (1 + \pi) - 2) + \pi .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 458, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 339, 89]]<|/det|>
Let \(a\) be a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 462, 121]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C_{1}\) has equation \(y = \frac{x - a}{x - 2a}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 245, 152]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C_{1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 764, 435]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C_{2}\) has equation \(y = \left(\frac{x - a}{x - 2a}\right)^{2}\) . The curve \(C_{3}\) has equation \(y = \left|\frac{x - a}{x - 2a}\right|\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 180, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 598, 463]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points of \(C_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 728, 91]]<|/det|>
Find also the coordinates of any points of intersection of \(C_2\) and \(C_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 102, 917, 119]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 135, 917, 153]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 170, 917, 188]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 203, 917, 221]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 337, 917, 355]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 370, 917, 388]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 403, 917, 421]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 146, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C_2\) and \(C_3\) on a single diagram, clearly identifying each curve. Hence find the set of values

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 529, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
of \(x\) for which \(\left(\frac{x - a}{x - 2a}\right)^2 \leqslant \left|\frac{x - a}{x - 2a}\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 415, 91]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) has position vector \(t\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 848, 121]]<|/det|>
Given that the shortest distance between the lines \(AB\) and \(CD\) is \(\sqrt{10}\), find the value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
